title: Life of the Jackal
text: Much has been written about the interwar “golden age” of detective fiction. So, too, about the Bond-mania that followed. The rich crop of conspiracy thrillers from the 1970s, however, has yet to receive its due. As with its cinematic contemporary, “New Hollywood,” the genre and its heroes reflected the era’s Vietnam- and Watergate-fired skepticism. Loren Singer’s “The Parallax View” (1970), Frederick Forsyth’s “The Day of the Jackal” (1971) and “The Odessa File” (1972), William Goldman’s “Marathon Man” (1974), James Grady’s “Six Days of the Condor” (1974), and others transported readers into the dark and deadly...
